questions.question: A 45 y/o male presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and persistent heartburn. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals multiple duodenal ulcers. Lab investigations show elevated serum gastrin levels (> 1000 pg/ml). Which features are most likely associated with the patient's condition?

options.A: Presence of gastrin-secreting tumors in the stomach
options.B: Presence of erosive esophagitis and hiatal hernia
options.C: Hyperplasia of parietal cells within the stomach

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hyperplasia of parietal cells within the stomach Explanation: The characteristic features described in the scenario, including recurrent abdominal pain, heartburn, multiple duodenal ulcers, and elevated serum gastrin levels, strongly suggest a diagnosis of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. A hallmark feature of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is marked hyperplasia of parietal cells within the stomach, leading to increased oxyntic mucosal thickness induced by excessive gastrin secretion from gastrinomas. Presence of gastrin-secreting tumors in the stomach (Option A): Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) is characterized by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors called gastrinomas. However, these tumors are predominantly found in the small intestine or pancreas rather than the stomach. The most common extrapancreatic site of gastrinoma is the duodenum. Presence of erosive esophagitis and hiatal hernia (Option B): These features are commonly associated with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), not Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. ZES primarily presents with duodenal ulcers or chronic diarrhea due to excessive gastric acid secretion from gastrinomas. Association with MEN2 gene mutation (Option D): Gastrinomas are sporadic in 75% of cases. Approximately 25% of patients with gastrinomas have MEN1 (not MEN2), which is linked to aggressive tumor behaviour and primarily presents with duodenal tumors. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 773

questions.question: A 60-year-old man presents with vague abdominal discomfort and early satiety. Imaging reveals a large mass in the gastric fundus. He undergoes surgical resection of the mass, and histopathology confirms a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). Which of the following factors is a favorable prognostic indicator of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Gastric location Explanation: Prognostic factors of GISTs Features Good prognosis Bad prognosis Tumor size < 5cm >10cm (Option A) Mitotic rate < 5 per HPF >10 per HPF Location Gastric Intestinal (Jejunum, Ileum, Rectum) (Option D) Cell type Spindle cell type Epithelioid cell type (Option B) Mutations Wild type GIST (Lack mutations in KIT, PDGFR) Specific PDGFRA mutations, such as the D842V mutation in exon 18 Treatment Responds to Tyrosine kinase inhibitors. Resistant to Tyrosine kinase inhibitors. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 778 https://www.uptodate.com/cont ents/clinical-presentation-diagnosis-and-prognosis-of-gastrointestinal-stromal-tumors?search=GIST&source=sear ch_result&selectedTitle=1%7E81&usage_type=default&display_rank=1#H13

questions.question: Which of the following markers will help confirm the diagnosis of GIST in C-kit negative cases?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) DOG1 Explanation: DOG1 (Discovered On GIST-1) is a highly sensitive and specific marker for GISTs (Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor), especially in C-kit-negative cases. CD34 (Option A): CD34 is a cell surface marker often expressed in GISTs. However, CD34 positivity alone cannot confirm GIST diagnosis, especially when C-kit mutation testing is negative. It aids in diagnosis, particularly when used alongside markers like DOG1. S-100(Option C): S100 is a marker commonly associated with neural and melanocytic tumors, not typically expressed in GISTs. CD117(Option D): CD117 (C-kit) expression is a hallmark of GISTs and is used as a most common diagnostic marker, but it does not confirm the diagnosis in the absence of C-kit mutations. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 778

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common mutation found in GIST (Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) KIT mutation Explanation: KIT (c-kit) is a proto-oncogene encoding a receptor tyrosine kinase. Mutations in KIT are the most common genetic abnormalities in GISTs, occurring in about 70-80% of cases. These mutations result in constant activation of KIT signaling, driving tumor growth and survival. PDGFRA mutation (Platelet-Derived Growth Factor Receptor Alpha) ( Option B): PDGFRA is a proto-oncogene that encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase. Mutations in PDGFRA occur in approximately 5-10% of GISTs and, similar to KIT mutations, drive tumor growth and progression by activating downstream signaling pathways. SDH mutation (Succinate Dehydrogenase) (Option C): SDH is a mitochondrial enzyme complex essential for cellular energy production. Mutations in genes encoding SDH subunits (SDHA, SDHB, SDHC, SDHD) are observed in SDH-deficient GISTs, which are also called KIT/PDGFRA wild-types as they lack KIT and PDGFRA mutations. These types of GIST are seen in cases with Carney-Stratakis syndrome (GIST + paraganglioma) or the Carney triad (GIST + paraganglioma + pulmonary chondroma). Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 779

questions.question: A 55-year-old man with intermittent abdominal pain, nausea, and early satiety has a palpable epigastric mass. Imaging shows a well-defined, heterogeneously enhancing stomach mass, and endoscopic biopsy reveals CD117-positive spindle cells. What is the likely origin of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Cajal cells Explanation: Gastro-intestinal Stromal Tumor: Cells of origin Cajal cells Mutations Most common- c-KIT/CD117 Others: PDGFR- beta S uccinate dehydrogenase (SDH)- S mall baby( Pediatric GIST) Mechanism c-KIT mutation- Increase in tyrosinase kinase activity Treatment Surgery Tyrosine Kinase inhibitors- Imatinib Goblet cells (Option B) : Goblet cells are specialized epithelial cells in the gastrointestinal tract, particularly in the intestines, that produce mucin to form protective mucus. Paneth cells (Option C): Paneth cells, located in the small intestine's crypts of Lieberk√ºhn, particularly in the ileum, secrete antimicrobial peptides like defensins and lysozyme to defend against bacterial infections. G cells (Option D): G cells are endocrine cells in the gastric antrum that produce gastrin, a hormone that stimulates gastric acid secretion. Dysfunctions in G cells can result in conditions like gastrinomas, seen in Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, which involves excessive gastric acid production and peptic ulcers. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 778

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with episodes of flushing, sweating, and colicky abdominal pain. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a yellow-tan intramural mass in the stomach. Biopsy revealed sheets of uniform cells with scant granular cytoplasm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Carcinoid tumor Explanation: Based on the patient's presentation and histological findings, the most likely diagnosis is a Carcinoid tumor that originates from scattered neuroendocrine cells in the GIT. They present with symptoms like flushing, bronchospasm, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and occasionally weight loss due to the secretion of vasoactive substances like serotonin, leading to carcinoid syndrome. Upper GI endoscopy may reveal yellow-tan intramural or submucosal masses. Histological examination often reveals cohesive cells with scant granular cytoplasm and stains positive for neuroendocrine markers like chromogranin A, synaptophysin, and leucine-7. Gastric outlet obstruction (Option B): Gastric outlet obstruction can be caused by conditions like gastric cancer or peptic ulcer disease in adults and infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis in children. The obstruction leads to decreased HCl secretion, resulting in metabolic alkalosis. Paradoxical aciduria may be a compensatory mechanism through the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (Option C): Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a congenital condition characterized by hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction in infants. It presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting, an olive-shaped lump palpable in the abdomen, and failure to thrive. Crohn's disease (Option D): Crohn's disease is a chronic granulomatous inflammation that affects the entire gastrointestinal tract, characterized by non-caseating granulomas with epithelioid histiocytes, lymphocytes, and multinucleated giant cells. It also shows intramural masses or strictures with patchy inflammation and "skip lesions" observed on endoscopy. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 777, 778

questions.question: A 48-year-old female presents with recurrent abdominal pain, bloating, and early satiety for the past few months. Endoscopic biopsy revealed lympho-epithelial lesions with infiltration of small lymphoid cells. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

options.D: Presents as discrete small nodules in the GI tract

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Plasmacytic differentiation seen The given presentation and biopsy findings suggest gastric MALT lymphoma , a type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma originating from the stomach's mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT). It is characterised by a dense lymphocytic infiltrate in the lamina propria , creating lympho-epithelial lesions indicative of B-cell involvement (not neutrophilic infiltration - Option A). Gastric MALToma involves B-cell follicles (not T-cell follicles - Option B). About 40% of gastric MALTomas show plasmacytic differentiation . Gastric MALT lymphoma typically presents as diffusely thickened gastric mucosa with a granular appearance on endoscopy (discrete nodules are not seen - Option D). Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 777

questions.question: A 45-year-old female has a history of intermittent epigastric discomfort, nausea, and early satiety. Upper endoscopy reveals gastric wall thickening with a leather bottle appearance. Biopsy of the lesion shows signet ring cells infiltrating the gastric mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Diffuse-type gastric adenocarcinoma The given findings suggest diffuse-type gastric adenocarcinoma, characterised by diffuse thickening of the gastric wall and signet ring cells infiltrating the gastric mucosa. Features Intestinal type Gastric adenocarcinoma (Option A) Diffuse-type gastric adenocarcinoma (Option B) Location Predominantly in the antrum or pyloric region Diffuse involvement of gastric body and fundus Risk factors H. pylori infection, high intake of smoked/pickled foods, smoking, chronic gastritis, old age CDH1 gene mutation, younger age Appearance on endoscopy Ulcerative, polypoid masses (localised growth) Thickening of gastric wall (due to diffuse infiltration). Linitis plastica (leather bottle appearance) Histology Well-differentiated glandular structures with intestinal metaplasia. Signet ring cells and infiltration of poorly cohesive cells into the gastric mucosa. Prognosis Better Poorer Peptic Ulcer Disease (PUD) (Option C) presents with discrete ulcerations with well-defined margins on endoscopy and microscopically shows ulceration with necrosis and fibrosis . Gastric Lymphoma ( Option D) typically arises from mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) and presents as focal or multifocal lesions, but it does not typically cause diffuse thickening of the gastric wall. The lesions are characterised by lymphoid cell infiltration but no signet ring cells are seen.

questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with a history of epigastric pain, unintentional weight loss, and early satiety over the past few months. An upper GI endoscopy revealed a nodular mass on the gastric wall, and a biopsy revealed well-differentiated glandular structures with intestinal metaplasia. Which of the following is least likely associated with this condition?

options.D: High intake of smoked or pickled foods

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) CDH1 gene mutation Explanation: The clinical presentation and biopsy revealing well-differentiated glandular structures with intestinal metaplasia suggest the diagnosis of ‚ÄòIntestinal type of gastric cancer‚Äô, which has no significant association with CDH-1 gene mutation. Mutations in the CDH1 gene (E-cadherin), associated with hereditary diffuse gastric cancer (HDGC), can lead to an increased risk of diffuse-type gastric cancer but not related to the intestinal type of gastric cancer. Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection (Option A): H. pylori infection is highly associated with intestinal-type gastric cancer as this bacterium causes chronic inflammation and atrophic gastritis, leading to intestinal metaplasia. APC gene mutation(Option B): The APC gene mutation is primarily associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and colorectal cancer. In intestinal-type gastric cancer, APC mutations may contribute to dysregulated Wnt signaling pathways, leading to aberrant cell growth and adenoma-carcinoma progression. High intake of smoked or pickled foods (Option D): Diets high in smoked or pickled foods are specifically associated with an increased risk of intestinal-type gastric cancer due to exposure to nitrosamines and other carcinogens present in these food preparations. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 775

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a recognised risk factor for gastric adenocarcinoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Blood group O Explanation: Blood group O is not a specific risk factor for gastric adenocarcinoma, but blood group A is a recognised risk factor. Gastric adenocarcinoma develops from the glandular cells of the stomach that produce acid and digestive enzymes. The risk factors for gastric adenocarcinoma include : Alcohol (Option A) Smoking Hot beverages (Option B) Smoked and salted food Pernicious anemia Adenomatous polyps Blood group A H. pylori infection (Option D) Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 774

questions.question: Which cells are primarily responsible for secreting neutral mucin that forms a protective layer in the stomach?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Foveolar cells Explanation: The neutral mucin that forms the protective mucosal layer in the stomach is mainly secreted by 'Foveolar cells' located in the surface lining of the stomach mucosa. This mucus secretion helps to protect the stomach lining from the acidic environment and mechanical stress associated with digestion. Cells of the stomach and their function Cells Functions Parietal cells (Option A) Secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factor. Chief cells (Option B) Secrete pepsinogen (Inactive precursor of the pepsin). Foveolar cells Secrete neutral mucin and form a protective layer over the stomach lining. Enterochromaffin cells (Option D) Release of serotonin and histamine to regulate gastric functions. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 764

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with persistent abdominal discomfort, nausea, weight loss, and occasional diarrhoea. He was recently diagnosed with a viral infection. The following gross image of the gastric mucosa is observed upon upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. Which of the following is correct regarding the patient's condition? Œ± .

options.A: Associated with excessive secretion of TNF-
options.C: Increases the risk of gastric carcinoma.
options.D: More common in females and can cause protein-losing enteropathy.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) It increases the risk of gastric carcinoma. Explanation: The endoscopic picture reveals thickened or giant gastric folds in line with Menetrier's disease. Menetrier's disease, a rare gastric disorder, more common in males. (Option D) It is associated with an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma. (Option C). It is associated with excessive TGF- Œ± secretion, often triggered by viral or H. pylori infection, primarily affecting the gastric body and fundus. (Option A) Pathogenesis involves hyperactivation of EGFR due to TGF- Œ± , resulting in diffuse foveolar epithelial hyperplasia and potential systemic effects like organ hyperplasia and tissue loss. Protein-losing enteropathy is common, with significant albumin loss (up to 10g/day) across gastric mucosa. Histopathology reveals elongated, cystic foveolar mucous cell hyperplasia, often accompanied by modest inflammation and glandular atrophy. (Option B) Management often includes supportive care with IV albumin, nutritional supplementation, and anti-EGFR antibodies

questions.question: A 58-year-old female presents with recurrent epigastric discomfort and intermittent nausea. Histopathological examination of gastric biopsy samples reveals irregular, cystically dilated, and elongated foveolar glands. She also has a history of untreated H. pylori infection. What type of lesions is most likely to be associated with these findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Hyperplastic polyps Based on the patient's symptoms, endoscopic findings, and history of untreated H. pylori infection, hyperplastic (or inflammatory) polyps are the most likely associated lesion. Hyperplastic Polyps: Frequently associated with H. pylori infection and is prevalent in the elderly with chronic gastritis. Typically manifest as multiple lesions , <1 cm and may exhibit superficial erosions. Histologically, these are characterised by irregular, cystically dilated, elongated foveolar glands with inflammation. The risk of dysplasia increases with size, especially in pedunculated polyps >1 cm in diameter. Gastric adenomas (Option B) Prevalent in older males. questions.question: Which type of gastritis is associated with a distinctive endoscopic appearance characterised by thickened folds, small nodules, and central aphthous ulceration affecting the entire stomach?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Lymphocytic gastritis Explanation: The clinical presentation, with the characteristic endoscopic appearance of thickened folds, small nodules, and central aphthous ulcerations affecting the entire stomach, suggests Lymphocytic gastritis or Varioliform gastritis. It is associated with increased intraepithelial T lymphocytes and may be linked to celiac disease. Eosinophilic gastritis ( Option A): Eosinophilic gastritis is characterised by dense infiltrates of eosinophils in the gastric mucosa and muscularis, commonly in the antral or pyloric region. It is often linked to allergies like cow‚Äôs milk or soy protein, particularly in children, and it does not present with the distinctive endoscopic appearance described in the scenario. Granulomatous gastritis (Option C): Granulomatous gastritis contains granulomas and can be caused by various conditions, including Crohn's disease, sarcoidosis, and certain infections. It is not associated with the given endoscopic appearance. Chemical gastritis (Option D): Chemical gastritis, also known as reactive gastropathy, is characterised by mucosal changes resulting from exposure to irritants like NSAIDs, alcohol, or bile reflux. This can lead to inflammation, erosion, and ulceration of the gastric mucosa. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 769

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents with chronic epigastric pain, nausea, and occasional vomiting. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals diffuse mucosal atrophy. Biopsy confirms chronic gastritis. Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Chronic Gastritis Type A?

options.A: Predominantly affects the antrum of the stomach

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Autoimmune destruction of parietal cells Explanation: Characteristic Chronic Gastritis Type A Chronic Gastritis Type B Location Fundus and body of the stomach Antrum and pyloric region of the stomach (Option A) Aetiology Autoimmune H. pylori infection or NSAID use Pathophysiology Autoimmune destruction of parietal cells (Option B) H. pylori-induced inflammation of gastric mucosa (Option C) Autoantibodies Autoantibodies against parietal cells and Antibodies against intrinsic factors ( ‚Üì Vit B12 absorption). Not autoimmune; may have H. pylori antibodies. Intrinsic factor Reduced due to parietal cell destruction. It may be normal unless atrophic gastritis is present. Gastric acid production Autoantibodies against parietal cells lead to decreased/absent HCl secretion and ‚Üë gastrin synthesis. Normal to increased acid secretion due to H. pylori. Histological findings Lymphocytic and plasma cell infiltrate. Neutrophilic infiltrate, lymphoid follicles. Complications Pernicious anaemia, gastric carcinoid, adenocarcinoma. Peptic ulcers, gastric adenocarcinoma, MALToma. Risk of gastric carcinoma Low Increased, especially with H. pylori infection (Option D) Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 766, 767

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient presents with recurrent epigastric pain and signs of gastrointestinal bleeding. An upper endoscopy reveals gastric ulcers, and a biopsy is performed for further evaluation. Which stain is best for identifying the causative organism in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Modified Giemsa stain Explanation: The given clinical presentation suggests peptic ulcer disease (PUD), and the organism involved in this condition is Helicobacter pylori. Due to its high sensitivity and specificity, the Modified Giemsa stain is widely regarded as the gold standard for H. pylori detection. It selectively targets H. pylori bacteria, staining them pink to red against a blue or purple background. Warthin Starry silver stain (Option A): The Warthin-Starry silver stain is a specialised technique for visualising bacteria like Helicobacter pylori and Spirochetes. However, it is less commonly used than the Modified Giemsa stain for H. pylori due to its more complex procedure and lower sensitivity. Wright stain (Option B): The Wright stain is primarily used for staining blood cells and is not routinely employed for identifying H. pylori. Gram stain (Option D): The Gram stain is used to classify bacteria into Gram-positive and Gram-negative groups based on cell wall characteristics, but it is ineffective for visualising H. pylori.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a protective factor against Peptic Ulcer Disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Pepsin Explanation: Pepsin is not considered a protective factor for peptic ulcer disease (PUD). Excessive pepsin activity, especially in the presence of acid, can lead to tissue damage and ulcer formation. Therefore, pepsin is considered a contributing factor to ulceration rather than a protective factor against PUD. Peptic Ulcer Disease Protective factors Damaging factors Mucus (Option A) Bicarbonate (Option B) COX 1 (Option C) HCl Pepsin H.pylori Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 770

questions.question: A 45-year-old man experiences recurrent upper abdominal pain worsened after meals, unresponsive to over-the-counter antacids. Which of the following is NOT typically a risk factor for the patient‚Äôs presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Obesity Explanation: The patient's presentation may raise suspicion for gastrointestinal conditions like peptic ulcer disease (PUD), in which Helicobacter pylori infection (Option C), cocaine use (Option C), and cigarette smoking (Option C) are established risk factors. Obesity is not typically a common risk factor for PUD. (Option D) Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 770

questions.question: A 55-year-old female with traumatic brain injury undergoes emergency craniotomy and is now intubated in the neurosurgical ICU. She suddenly develops hematemesis despite stabilisation. What is the most likely cause of the patient's bleeding?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer:B) Cushing ulcer Explanation: In the given scenario, the patient's acute onset hematemesis following a traumatic brain injury and neurosurgical intervention suggests the likely development of a stress-related ulcer, particularly a Cushing ulcer. Feature Cushing's Ulcers (Option B) Curling Ulcers (Option A) Location Usually found in the stomach (cardia), oesophagus, or duodenum Typically occur in the proximal duodenum Associated condition Elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., head trauma, intracranial haemorrhage) Severe burns (involving >30% of body surface area) or trauma Pathogenesis Increased vagal activity stimulates gastric acid secretion, leading to ulcer formation. Result from decreased mucosal blood flow due to systemic hypotension or stress-induced vasoconstriction Ulcer characteristics Deep ulcers; increased risk of perforation. Superficial ulcers. Option C) Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE): GAVE presents as longitudinal stripes of edematous, erythematous mucosa alternating with paler mucosa, resembling a "watermelon stomach". It is a cause of non-stress-related upper GI bleeding, often associated with cirrhosis and systemic sclerosis. Option D) Dieulafoy lesions Dieulafoy lesions are abnormal submucous arterioles often found near the gastroesophageal junction in the stomach's lesser curvature, which can cause recurrent, sometimes severe, gastric bleeding. NSAID use can increase the bleeding risk, and it is a non-stress-related cause of GI bleeding. Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 766
